query: Summarize the discussion about the law as it presently stands.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the law should reflect contemporary society and the law is evolutionary in nature, and should be changed to reflect the way in which people behave within society. In respect of children in particular, the Children Act 2004 did make it a defence for a person accused of assaulting a child to argue that it was a case where they were acting only so as to impose reasonable punishment. By way of contrast, it was not available for an offence involving an adult.

query: Summarize the discussion about the divergence between the law in England and Wales from Barry Hughes.
summary: Barry Hughes explained that there was a spectrum of offending in England and Wales, and the CPS recognised this. There would be more cases that would pass the evidential stage in Wales than there would be in England, but it wouldn't be in the public interest to prosecute. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, Barry Hughes said they would build themselves up to come up with the appropriate guidance according to the circumstances.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the divergence of criminal law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it was probably the first time that there had been an obvious divergence between English and Welsh law, so it would be necessary to update the guidance. However, he did not see a need to update or amend the guidance because it went back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage. He thought they would need to develop more with respect to that.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the public interest test?
summary: Barry Hughes said that the public interest test was not as of the present day, but it was under way and they had regular interchange of prosecutors between England and Wales. They would need to make sure that those people were brought up to speed on the fact that there were some aspects of Welsh law that diverge from English law.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the burden of proof if the defence was removed?
summary: Barry Hughes explained that the burden of proof was going to work if this defence was removed, providing that it was clear that contact with a child had happened. The change in the law would afford children a degree of protection that they didn't presently have, but which they did have when they attained the age of 16.

query: What did the meeting talk about the implementation of the Act?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that they needed to maintain the type of dialogue that they had built up with the Welsh Government and colleagues there. They needed involvement from Iwan, for example, and the strategic implementation group. They had other members of my staff who were involved in the other work streams that feed through to that, and they believed that that involvement would ensure that they were sufficiently interconnected. Moreover, they had got a network of contacts built up here that was adequate for the purpose.

query: Summarize the discussion about the practical and possibly financial implications for the workforce in this legislation.
summary: Suzy Davies AM asked about the practical and possibly financial implications for the workforce in this legislation. Barry Hughes answered that there would be minor financial consequences for them and no significant financial consequences in the period between now and the Bill becoming law other than the time of themselves in discussing this today. Moreover, the numbers would be very small, which means they would be able to keep a clear track on those and, obviously, they would wish to keep the situation under review, and they would reach a period of time after whatever—12, 18 months, maybe 24 months—where they would look back to see how they were doing.

query: Summarize the discussion about the interests of the child when applying the public interest test.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, the essence of the public interest test was about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that was proportionate to the offending. There was a long list of matters that they took into account. Some of them were fairly obvious, such as previous convictions. If someone's got previous convictions for doing something wrong, it's more likely they're going to be prosecuted the next time. However, there was no part of the law that said that prosecution would always follow. So, they would tailor it to the circumstances of the particular incident to assess how the child felt about it.

query: Summarize the discussion about out-of-court disposals.
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. However, it was more unclear as to what was a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. There was a spectrum of offending, and life would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposals with more clarity about what each one of them involved.

query: What did the meeting talk about the unintended consequences?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that raising awareness was important, and he was pleased to see that the media publicity surrounding this proposed legislation, which was now going through, reached as far afield as New York and had widespread media coverage across England and Wales, and the Government would be well placed here to take advantage of that willingness of the media to explore something potentially divisive, and

query: What did the meeting talk about the unintended consequences of introducing the new law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the unintended consequences of introducing the new law would be very unlikely because they had had a pretty helpful canter through most of the circumstances here that might happen. The numbers, again, would be tiny, and dwarfed by the number of cases where they had to deal with the fallout between a relationship breakdown between partners—whether they be living within the same house or living in different houses. And, in his experience, the police were much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago, in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the costs of prosecuting cases made possible by the Bill?
summary: According to Barry Hughes, there is a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecute 5 per cent of those in any given year. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions is, for him, not a reason not to signify that certain behaviour is or is not acceptable. The criminal law provides a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand.

query: Summarize the discussion about the use of the mike type wireless
summary: The team was discussing the use of the mike type wireless for performing tasks on the computer network. query: Summarize the discussion about the speech enhancement algorithm.
summary: PhD A explained that the team had been working on a signal subspace approach for speech enhancement. The team had tried spectral subtraction, Wiener filtering, and on-line normalization, but the results were not very promising. They decided to move on to the next step, which was adding endpoint information to the baseline.

query: What did the professor think about spectral subtraction?
summary: The professor thought spectral subtraction was a good idea. He explained that the well-matched condition was unusual because it was always better than France Telecom for mismatch and high-mismatch, but it was still slightly worse for well-matched. He thought that the difference in performance was due to the amount of noise and the silence frames in the database. The professor also thought that it was important to have frame dropping.

query: Summarize the discussion about combining the Wiener filtering with signal subspace
summary: The team discussed the pros and cons of combining the Wiener filtering with signal subspace. The pros thought that combining the two techniques would improve the performance of the model, but the disadvantages were that it would require re-optimization of other things. The disadvantage was that the noise would not be removed from the model if it was noisy. The professor suggested that the team could try combining the techniques with spectral subtraction and the LDA filter.

query: What did the professor think about the FFT?
summary: The professor thought that the FFT was a good idea because it was able to discriminate between speech and nonspeech. However, he was concerned that the variability in the power spectrum was too great. He thought that it was important to know if there was something useful in the difference between the filter bank and FFT. He suggested that the neural network could learn something from it.

query: Summarize the discussion about formants
summary: Grad G explained that he was helping a speech researcher named Pierre Divenyi with his work on how people respond to formant changes. He was building robust primary detectors for the LPC spectrum and using the outputs of these robust detectors to do speech recognition. The team discussed whether they should get the formants directly from the synthesizer or not.

query: Summarize the discussion about the intermediate nodes.
summary: The intermediate nodes would be the endpoint decision as seen from the user model, the ontology and the discourse. The ontology would have properties that could contribute to whether a person wants to enter, view, or approach something. The discourse would be a place of business, a landmark, and an accessible endpoint. The professor suggested that they could merge the three intermediate nodes.

query: What did the professor think about user interests?
summary: The professor thought that user interests should be treated as a vector of several possible things, like Gothic churches versus Baroque townhouses versus a landmark. User interests could include selling things, fixing things, service things, exhibiting things, and being a landmark at the same time as doing these things. The professor also suggested that they should get rid of the long link between who the user is and the endpoint.

query: What did the professor think about user state?
summary: The professor thought that the current model of user state was sufficient for now, but that there was still work to be done on the situation model and the discourse model. He thought that it would be useful to have a set of decisions that could be fed into the Go-there endpoint. The professor also suggested that they could create an intermediate node that just the Endpoint and the Go - there S node sort of fed into.

query: Summarize the discussion about the organization of the data
summary: The team was discussing how to organize the data. The professor proposed that the data should be sorted into sub-decisions, which would be fed into various discourse-based decision nodes. The team agreed that the decision nodes should be in the order of the utterance, the discourse, the situation, and the discourse history. They also discussed how to deal with the ambiguity in the discourse.

query: Summarize the discussion about decision nodes
summary: The team discussed how to deal with the problem of decision nodes. The professor suggested that the decision nodes should be dealt with by a mixture of experts, and that they could either be built into the net or combined into a weighted combination. The decision nodes could be given a single weight to each expert, or they could be combined in a weighted way. The team also discussed the probability distribution of each decision node and how it could be derived from the data.

query: Summarize the discussion about the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification.
summary: According to Sian Gwenllian, most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses. And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh baccalaureate, what does it offer, and whether that's developing the skills that employers require. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. Therefore, the understanding is quite limited amongst the employers they work with.

query: Summarize the discussion about improving employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate.
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM suggested that they should review the qualification, and the voice of employers should be a key part of that review, so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills had more of a role within the qualification. Dafydd Evans agreed and suggested that the Welsh baccalaureate was one of them, but it was not the one that engaged employers the best, certainly in their college. They needed to be far more clever in terms of how they joined these things up, and then they would start to get that business input there.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the baccalaureate?
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, one of the problems is that there are a number of priorities. The baccalaureate is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification. But when learners are focused, if they are a learner, on developing or achieving certain qualifications to make up the Welsh baccalureate, which is a huge amount of work, then they lose the focus on the skills, which are ultimately what were supposed to be part of the development for employability. So, the priorities, I think, across the sector should be reviewed, to look at how they could make skilled and employable people.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: The Welsh baccalaureate was valued differently at the different levels that it was studied. At level 1 and level 2, it was not what they would call a crowd puller in colleges, but at level 3 it was more, especially for A-levels, because it could help them get into university. For the more able and talented, four A-Levels were better. At the same time, at post-16 national and foundation level, increasingly, the Welsh bac was not being offered.

query: Summarize the discussion about universities in the main understanding the value of the Welsh baccalaureate.
summary: According to Kay Martin, they don't think they do, really, especially the experience they have with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. Some of the universities are not valuing the Welsh baccalaureate. And the important point that Dafydd raised was that there's a lot of repetition there in school, pre 16 to post 16 at those levels as well. So, they need to consider that.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the quality of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Julie Morgan AM asked about the quality of the Welsh baccalaureate. Dafydd Evans answered that it had become a very rigorous, very large qualification. Actually, it's probably larger than an A-level by now. And the investment they had to put into WorldSkills was huge. So, for some of their learners, they choose that you do WorldSkill, because that was going to be more valuable for you as a skill, and to show to an employer how much extra time they had put in. And, therefore, regarding the rigour and so forth, that was absolutely fine, as long as it was right for that learner's future. But if a learner wanted to go into a particular sector and they were not accepted, it was not comparable.

query: What did Dr Rachel Bowen think about the skills being developed in the Welsh bac?
summary: Dr Rachel Bowen thought the baccalaureate approach was best at producing independent, inquiry-based learners who had the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. But Dr Rachel Bowen would go back to the point that a comparable qualification was comparable as long as it achieved the right outcome for that particular learner.

query: Summarize the discussion about universal adoption.
summary: According to Suzy Davies, most of the colleges across Wales did not use the baccalaureate as a recruitment tool because most of them, as you see, they value the Welsh bac. However, they had had witnesses who said that it would be a good idea because it reduced the amount of competition and advantage that certain institutions had. Therefore, they wouldn't deliberately tell people, "Come on in and you won't have to do it."

query: What did the meeting talk about the bac?
summary: The baccalaureate should be seen as an important part of creating a rounded individual ready for employment. The qualifications were well catered for. There was a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So, I don't think it was a case of squeezing things out.

query: What did Nick Brazil think of the question of whether the Welsh baccalaureate was the correct way of approaching education?
summary: The Welsh baccalaureate was one of the first questions that people always asked. It was generally a question that people asked, and the learners usually had not had the best experience pre 16 and that's why they asked the question straight away. The answer was that it was about offering the full range of qualification opportunities for learners. If they didn't offer the range, which, sometimes—if you, obviously, limit and made qualifications compulsory, that can limit the choice of opportunities as well.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh bac?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that there were certainly instances of young people coming in with quite a negative attitude originally, originally, to the Welsh baccalaureate and taking it on board. But where they were delivering it well, well contextualised, they had really enjoyed the experience, and very much valued the experience. However, it would be very difficult for them, as institutions, to change the negative perception. It would make it into quite an intensive selling process for colleges when they had got to overcome that negative perception and so on.

query: Summarize the discussion about the universal adoption.
summary: According to Kay Martin, if a few years ago, they were all heading for universal adoption, but because the Welsh baccalaureate had changed into something that wasn't 100 per cent what they thought it should be, they had stopped the universal adoption. Now they were trying to do what's in the best interests of the learner, but they were not sure at the moment. Therefore, they needed to go back to the original vision of the Welsh bachelor's degree, which all of them would buy into 100 percent. They needed to spend less time in checking what they had done on assessment and more time in the doing, and the experiential learning that they need to do, rather than it being too much of a paper exercise.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the progress of the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, there had been broad support for the curriculum changes that they were proposing. There had been a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. They were also looking to include in the legislation provision for a statutory framework setting out their approach to progression in each of the AoLE areas. In terms of some of the things that people were asking them to look again at, some of that was around some language used. So, they would make a statutory provision for the 'what matters' statements.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the religious education and relationships and sexuality education?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, these two areas certainly have ensured that lots of people have responded. They felt that that that was an important part of preparing a young person to live in a world that was, as you say, diverse with people of different views living in it. There was a need for learners, as they saw it, to be prepared to be part of a diverse and multicultural society. There were mixed views on the inclusion of a range of faiths and world religions included in that area of learning. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views.

query: What did the meeting talk about the potential unintended consequences of the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, the expectation was that they would publish a final version of the curriculum in January 2020, so schools would then have the opportunity to be really engaging in it. There were some issues raised about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. However, Kirsty insisted that the curriculum would be implemented in September.

query: What did the meeting talk about the segregation within schools between different groups of pupils?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, the curriculum in itself was neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum was what's taught in our schools. What would make the curriculum a success for all of our children were the four enabling purposes of the curriculum, which were strong leadership of our schools that ensured that there was no segregation, that had high expectation of all the children, and delivered a curriculum within that setting that met the needs of the children there. Moreover, the teachers were absolutely crucial to this, which was why, first of all, they had taken the difficult step to delay the implementation of the new curriculum to give them the time that they needed to make sure that it was not just school leaders but it was individual classroom practitioners who had the skills that would be able to make the most of the opportunity that the new school had to offer. Finally, there would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales.

query: Summarize the discussion about the lessons learned from the introduction of their curriculum.
summary: According to Kirsty, the first thing to realise was that their curriculum was not a copycat of the Scottish curriculum, but it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that had arisen. Also, one of the critical elements was the extent to which assessment was considered at the outset alongside the curriculum content. So, they had embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of their curriculum assessment group. Finally, they encouraged schools to go forth and multiply in terms of the materials and ideas and concepts that were coming through.

query: Summarize the discussion about the preparation for the implementation.
summary: Dawn Bowden AM asked about the preparation for the implementation. Kirsty Williams AM answered that they had set aside about £24 million over two years, which was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. They were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they didn't think they had done that on a consistently good level across the country. And they were interested in looking at some of the practices that other countries used to include pupil voice to find out what's happening.

query: Summarize the discussion about the issue of teachers who are not trained in Wales.
summary: According to Kirsty, they would continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales will teach in England and teachers who have worked in England will come across the border, as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in Wales. They would have a mix of sector—secondary, primary—but also linguistically, to just try to make sure that this works in all the different types of schools. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. They did not have a monitoring system that said, "Tick every box".

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the accountability?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM thought that there would be an independent review of performance measurements coming shortly, and that some of the existing ones had been ditched in fairly recent legislation. There would be a greater emphasis on self-evaluation, with external verification of that by Estyn, the inspectors. The primary purpose for assessment was for the professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on, and the purpose for categorization was not to make a judgment on a school in the sense of a league table.

query: What did the meeting talk about the public assurance at those early steps of the teaching standards and the leadership standards?
summary: According to Kirsty, the first level of accountability in that system had to be the professionalism of an individual member of staff and the moral purpose that they brought to their work. Then, the schools would be publishing self-evaluations annually, and the outcome of that would be a school development plan. The measures would still consider reflection on progress of children, but it would also have reviews of mental health, well-being, how it approaches that and things that it wanted to do. The schools' ability would be judged by Estyn.

query: Summarize the discussion about the Welsh dimension in the new curriculum.
summary: The Learned Society of Wales suggested that there needs to be a directory of resources to implement the Welsh dimension. Kirsty Williams agreed with that and said that they have a separate programme of work that is looking at resources that are needed to support the curriculum. The continuum for language would have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child was being taught, and there would be progression points on that continuum to show progression both in Welsh language and in the English language.

query: What did the meeting discuss about physical activity?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked about the guarantee that all children and young people, where appropriate, would take part in physical activity under the new curriculum for Wales. Kirsty Williams AM answered that they would be given that opportunity, because if they were not then that school would be in breach of the expectations that would be set out in statute. Also, how much time per week would the Government expect young people to spend undertaking physical activity?

query: Summarize the discussion about governance arrangements.
summary: According to Kirsty, statutory and non-statutory provision had been involved in the development of the curriculum because, of course, some of this was going to be delivered in the non-Statutory sector. However, they were carrying on with the same governance set-up, the different groups that they had got, and there was nothing being added there or taken away. They would be setting a minimum standard around the purposes, around the cross-cutting themes and health and well-being, and then there would be an expectation that in conjunction with the child and the family an appropriate addition would be put in place to meet the needs of that child, recognising that they could have very different needs.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the three steps of making the remote control.
summary: The group discussed the three steps of making the remote control. The first step was the functional design, that was very important. The second was the conceptual design. The third was the detailed design, which was exactly how it looked and whatever. The group discussed what the market was doing for what kind of remote controls were in the market.

query: What did the group discuss about drawing animals on the whiteboard?
summary: Marketing drew a fish on the whiteboard. Industrial Designer drew a worm. User Interface drew a dog. Project Manager suggested that the animal should be an animal that lives in the water.

query: What did the group discuss about universal remote control?
summary: Marketing first asked if it had to be a universal remote control because they sell it lonely from the remote control and not with the television. Project Manager thought it was not a good question because they sold it apart from the television, so Project Manager was not sure. Industrial Designer thought it probably would be universal because it was a picture. User Interface thought it would be only for television and not for more devices. So the group agreed to just say that it was universal. The production cost were about half the price of selling price. The profit was fifty million Euros.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested making the remote control in the same style as the television, but User Interface argued that it should not be too big because it had to have a lot of functions, so the group decided to make something like mobile phones that users could fold open. Also, the group agreed that the remote should be clear so that kids and the elderly could use it easily. However, they did not want to use a touchscreen because they thought it would be too expensive.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the remote control should be kid-proof and the on off button should be on top. They also agreed to put the basic things on the same place, like the TV channels one two three four as a block, and then the volume obviously on top so that users can see. The group also agreed that a home station was a good idea because lots of people were lost their remote control and didn't know where it was.

query: What did the group discuss about button design of the remote control?
summary: The group discussed about button design of the remote control. The User Interface proposed to keep it like a square, just normal remote control, but the Project Manager pointed out that it would be hard to make it fold open and the strength was not as good as a normal one. The group also discussed about what kind of buttons were in the market, what was normal, and what kinds of buttons people needed on their remote controls.

query: Summarize the discussion about data collection and summarization
summary: The team agreed that it would be helpful to collect more data from different types of meetings. The professor suggested that the team could collect data from a variety of domains, such as linguistics, psychology, and social science. The team also discussed the feasibility of collecting data from remote meetings.

query: Summarize the discussion about the disk space.
summary: The team thought that they had enough space on the current disk space to record four more meetings. They were getting a new disk rack and four thirty-six gigabyte disks, but that was not going to happen instantaneously. They needed to figure out a way to get more people to contribute to the project.

query: What did the team discuss about the overlapping zones?
summary: The team discussed the overlapping zones and how to classify them. The overlapping zones were classified using a sup supervised and hierarchical clustering process. The team decided that the best way would be to use a cluster or a neural net to classify speech and overlapping speech.

query: What did the professor think about detecting the acoustic change?
summary: The professor thought that detecting the acoustic change was a good idea. He thought that the team should start with the simpler signal and work their way up to the more sophisticated one. He also suggested that the model should be able to detect overlapping sounds.

query: What did the team discuss about the anonymization?
summary: The team discussed whether to delay the anonymization or to present the results next week. Postdoc E suggested that the results should be presented in the next meeting. The team discussed the importance of the data collection and how to ensure that the data is not misidentified. They also discussed whether it would be a good idea to use the same name for the speaker identifier and also in the text whenever the speaker's name is mentioned.

query: What did the team discuss about the transcript?
summary: The team discussed how to best use the transcript. The professor thought that the team should not change the names in the transcript because it would be a mistake to do so. The team also discussed whether they should keep the transcripts in the same order or bleep out certain words. They decided to keep the transcript as is for the time being.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the presentation on the last meeting.
summary: Marketing gave a presentation about the findings of the last meeting. The first point was that seventy five percent of the users found most remote controls ugly and seventy-five percent of users thought it was hard to make a beautiful remote control. The second point was about the basic functions like numbers and the on-off button. The group agreed that they had to make it a special product for elderly people. The last point about the usability was that they should make it easy to use and stand out by just looks of it.

query: What did the group discuss about button design of the remote control?
summary: User Interface suggested that the remote control should stand out from other remote controls by having a different shape and be unique with the design so that it stands out from the other ones in the market. Industrial Designer suggested that there should be a menu button and a light emitting and a visible button to go to the channel you've been before. Project Manager agreed and suggested that they could make a mute button to indicate that the TV was working. However, Project Manager was not satisfied with this idea because he thought it would be too difficult for old people. So the group decided to keep it simple and standard and integrate it in the design.

query: What did the group discuss about the energy source of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the energy source of the remote control should be the battery. However, they had to understand what patterns were used to make it universal so that it could be used with all the TVs. They also agreed to make a more intelligent chip than the standard one so that the new product could be flashy and more interesting.

query: What did the group discuss about the buttons on the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the buttons on the remote control should be easy to find and easy to use. They also agreed that they should make the buttons in the dark as well as in different colours and fonts. However, they did not agree to put the option of speech recognition on the second level because they thought it was not useful enough.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the basic design of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the material of the remote control should be hard plastic, and the buttons should be made of rubber. The group also agreed that there should be two D buttons, on-off buttons, text buttons, mute buttons, and scrollwheel buttons.

query: Summarize the discussion about the button design of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the buttons should be made of hard plastic and the colour should be red, green, and yellow. The group also agreed that there should be a text button on the remote control.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the remote control.
summary: Marketing thought the remote control was easy to use, but it was not as fast as a usual remote control. User Interface thought the scrollwheel, backlights, slide and speech function were new, but the second part, like speech, was harder to learn. Project Manager thought the slide was not new and the backlight was unnecessary. The group agreed that the scroll wheel was pretty cool, but Project Manager didn't know if it was reachable. The team also agreed on the colour, backlight, speech function and the home station.

query: Summarize the team's evaluation of the project.
summary: The team agreed that there was room for creativity in the project. The team also agreed that the team had followed the latest trends in the design of the remote control. However, the team thought that they got wrong information at the wrong time and the team was not too hard on themselves for not having a fancy design. They also agreed on the cost of the project, which was 12.3 Euros.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the decision of the project.
summary: The group decided to make a remote control from the old versions of the remote control, a universal device, and touch screens for all their stuff. They also agreed to save everything.

query: Summarize the presentation on the exterior of the remote.
summary: The remote would have a plastic body with a standard colour and a rubberised outer casing. The top screen would be an inset black and white LCD touch screen and the bottom screen would just contain the standard buttons, like the volume up and down, channel change, power on and off, and things to that effect. There would be a standard transmission with the TV using using all the standard chips. The infrared sender would be on one of the bottom layers. The voice recognition system would be in the top section rather than the bottom sections.

query: Summarize the team's evaluation of the prototype.
summary: The team evaluated the prototype based on the market research findings about the spongy texture to the exterior and the fruit and vegetable design colours. The team gave a preliminary rating of all the criteria on the whiteboard. They came to a consensus rating between one and seven.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation findings.
summary: Marketing summarized the evaluation findings. The team agreed that the prototype meeting the specifications was high enough at the upper end of the scale for the company to go ahead with the production. The lowest rating they got was for the minimisation of repetitive strain injury, which was close around neutral. In terms of the cost, Industrial Designer thought they were happy with the costs on that, and they could not do much more to minimise that. The group also agreed that it was easy to locate.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the cost of the remote control should be 12.5 Euros in Euros and 25 Euros in US dollars. They also agreed that they could change the battery to a standard one instead of a kinetic one, and they could offer the voice recognition initially to business class customers. However, they decided not to change the design specification because the exchange range would make it about twelve.

query: Summarize the team's evaluation of the project.
summary: Industrial Designer thought the meeting went well and everyone was listened to and all the points that were raised seemed to have been sorted out, although they didn't quite make the voice recognition in there. User Interface thought the team had a nice time and there was a lot of interaction between them. Marketing thought they had done room for creativity in the project because they were borrowing from other areas and adjusting their remit where necessary.

query: Summarize the discussion about the cost control of the project.
summary: Marketing thought the team had done a great job on the cost control of the project. The team agreed that they had done very well to get within budget. However, they had to increase the price of the remote control to meet the company's requirement of fifty percent profit, which meant that they would have to raise the cost of the product.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increase in exclusions from school.
summary: According to Sharon Davies, one of the things they were experiencing across the system in Wales was more examples of very challenging behaviour. Also, there were a lot of pressures on schools to perform, and the whole culture that the schools were within did play an element of it to some. Therefore, it was something that they needed to make sure that their staff and their schools were well-equipped to meet these needs, but there would always be some learners who needed more specialist provision. Moreover, there was a little bit of lag in the system, trying to bring everybody up to the same, consistent level. In terms of school accountability measures, they were seeing a change with the interim measures coming on board, but it was going to be a lag before they saw that having a knock-on effect on the learners.

query: What did the WLGA think about the additional learning needs sector being adversely affected?
summary: The WLGA thought that the additional learning needs sector was adversely affected by the very narrow measure at the end of key stage 4 attainment, which had put pressure on some schools, certainly, and headteachers had felt that—sometimes excluded, or otherwise put into another school as a consequence, which was regrettable, but that was what had happened. Moreover, the additional needs sector had to look at every aspect within the school in terms of their learners, then, and that did place additional pressure on the schools.

query: Summarize the discussion about the transition arrangements.
summary: According to Nick, at least one authority was looking at how they could best retain all pupils in the school setting, but it was early days yet for looking at that. There was an integration through a part-time timetable back into school, and they continued to support them during that process. It was looked at the whole package of support, which included not just the learner but the family, whether it was transport and also using the expertise that they did have within the sector to work more closely with their schools, and vice versa, particularly around the curriculum. And that was a model that, at the time, that local authority looked at to get more money into schools and to get schools, then, to have that responsibility—that they didn't offload the learners elsewhere.

query: What were the reasons for the delays that some children experience in accessing EOTAS?
summary: According to Nick Williams, some children experienced delays in accessing EOTAS because they just didn't have enough spaces in some cases, some year groups and so on. Also, for them as well they had reinvigorated their managed move provision and discussion. They had somebody who oversees that and worked very closely with their secondary schools so that they gave almost a second chance to learners. However, they didn't want to make it too difficult, so that the providers were not quite working now, and it was a little bit of a balancing act.

query: What did the meeting discuss about home tuition?
summary: According to Lynne Neagle, the purpose of the question was around home tuition that was commissioned by the local authority, but Nick Williams was not sure if that was a consistent answer for local authorities. He thought it was about getting that money following the learners and so on, and that shared ownership of the learner that the schools needed to keep, because they wanted them reintegrated back into schools. Therefore, it was in all their interests to do the very best for these learners.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the curriculum as it stands?
summary: According to Nick Williams, in general, they were happy with the way the curriculum was being delivered in the PRUs and PRUs were broad and balanced. It was more difficult where home tuition was provided by a third party that's been commissioned. However, the progress was quite positive currently, but there was still work to do. As for those who were in homes, or in private provision, particular things happen there, and they may not get that. The commissioning arrangements should ask for those things to be put into place; it was all about the monitoring then.

query: Summarize the discussion about the capacity of EOTAS provision.
summary: According to Dawn Bowden, there was a disconnect between what should be happening and what actually was happening. Even in some local authority PRUs where they expected all of this to be happening, they knew that it was not; they also knew that the full curriculum was not being provided either. The basic numeracy, literacy and well-being stuff was taking place, but there was discrepancy of provision, even in local authority commissioned EOTAS provision. There really wasn't the capacity for them to access professional training. However, the most recent inspection was very positive, and not that they recognised that there was no work to be done; they were not being complacent.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the lack of mental health support in mainstream schools?
summary: According to Nick Williams, there was a general deficit in child and adolescent mental health services, for example. There were three health boards over the footprint of the south-west and mid Wales region. Therefore, it was probably a more general issue there that would, in turn, translate into pupils who had got additional needs, whether they were in EOTAS, PRU or wherever. And they needed to look at the system holistically to be more prepared to deal with challenging behaviour.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increase in the numbers of children and young people being excluded from school.
summary: Dr Ian Johnson thought it was very concerning that they were seeing increases amongst younger children in particular. A lot of the evidence they were hearing was quite anecdotal, so it tended to be around the behavioural issues or underlying issues, and there was a lot of discussion about the adverse childhood experiences agenda and how that was affecting young people. So, he thought they needed to dig a bit deeper and understand the story behind that and whether there's a specific reason why schools were doing that, related to the accountability measures.

query: Summarize the discussion about the support provided to pupils who are at risk of becoming EOTAS.
summary: According to Dr Ian Johnson, there was no simple answer to this one because they didn't have a simple answer. However, there were a number of things that they need to do: they needed to recognise the impact of adverse childhood experiences and how that can help to drive distress and suicidal ideation. They also needed to train teachers so that they had an understanding response and were much more confident in that; they needed listen to the voices of young people themselves. They needed to get more of a child-centred voice around this. Finally, they should have a whole-school approach to the problem.

query: What did Dr. Ian Johnson think about the off-rolling?
summary: According to Dr. Ian Johnson, there were two questions within there, regarding the delay in entering provision and the effect of long term individual teaching. The first was whether there were actually delays in accessing EOTAS, especially at key stage 4, where obviously you would hold those grades. The second question was about the off-rolling. Dr Ian Johnson thought that there were a number of potential reasons for that. It could be the socio-economic profile, because exclusions, et cetera, were substantially higher amongst those who were eligible for free school meals, and in many parts of Wales the socioeconomic profile of a Welsh-medium education school was slightly different.

query: Summarize the discussion about the whole-school approach and ensuring that EOTAS provision includes this.
summary: According to Dr Ian, it was important for teachers to be equipped with the training and to understand the link between inequality and all the things that come under that term, and challenging behaviour, and if teachers were aware of that, and trained properly to deal with that, the risk of exclusion would ultimately lessen. Dr Ian also mentioned that the whole-school approach would work within EOTAS, and how they ensure that the provision was available through the medium of Welsh on a national level.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new project requirements.
summary: Firstly, the new project requirements were that the remote control should only be used for television, because teletext was out of date and internet was replacing teletext. Secondly, the product should be aimed at customers younger than forty. Thirdly, the corporate image should be recognisable in the product.

query: What did the group discuss about the button design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the buttons to zap and volume were the most important and that they should be designed with a perfect design for those only those buttons. The group also agreed to incorporate a sound signal into the design of the remote control.

query: What did the group discuss about the user interface of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the most important thing for people is that there's a central point to which they can go and perform some kind of function, such as channel selection, volume selection and teletext, so the remote control should have such a function, if it's possible within the costs and all that kind of things. However, Project Manager pointed out that by implementing this kind of a function the technical design would become more complicated, so they should skip it.

query: Summarize the discussion about the user interface.
summary: The user interface should be simple with few buttons, trendy design, nice lightning effects and the sound. It should be easy to use and user-friendly. query: Summarize the discussion about meeting data and transcriptions
summary: The team had been collecting meeting data and preparing a spreadsheet with start time, the date, the new meeting name, the number of speakers, the duration of the meeting, comments, and the transcription status. query: What did the team think about the VTL?
summary: The team thought that the VTL was working well. The team noticed that the pitch features were better in the close-talking mikes. They also noticed that there were fewer halvings and doublings and fewer dropouts. They were also getting better signals in the data, which was a good sign. However, the team was concerned that the model was not generalizing well.

query: What did the professor think about the front-end?
summary: The professor thought that it was not uncommon for recorded electronics to have different DC offsets. He thought that the front-end of the model should not be too different from a properly trained Gaussian, but it should at least be roughly the same and maybe a little better. The professor was concerned that there could be a bug in the way they were feeding the tandem features into the model.

query: Summarize the discussion about the normalization of the inputs to the net
summary: The team was discussing the normalization of the inputs to the net. The professor explained that the net was trained on a Viterbi alignment of the training data that came from the full system, but it was not optimized for phone discrimination. The team thought that they could optimize the features for the final word error by doing a KLT transform on the combined feature vector, but the professor pointed out that this might not be feasible since they were not using the net for recognition.

query: What did the professor think about the noise?
summary: The professor thought that the noise was affecting the model performance. He thought that a lot of it was below a hundred hertz and that the model should be able to take advantage of a larger training set. The professor also mentioned that the team had a video projector in the room and that was a nice noise source. The team was also trying to fix the noise using the clean subset of the Wall Street Journal, which was a pretty low frequency kind of thing.

query: What did the professor think about the latency?
summary: The professor thought that the model was pretty good, but still needed work. He thought the delta was too high. The professor explained that the VAD was used for on-line normalization, and the delta at the input was used before the delta computation. The delta was also used for smoothing. He also mentioned that there was some continuity built into the model, presumably to handle some inertia in the production system.

query: What did the professor think about the model?
summary: The professor thought that the model was doing well on the well-matched and the mismatched conditions, but it was getting worse on the highly mismatched. The model was getting better on the high-mismatched cases, but not as good on the low-matched ones. The professor thought it was important to learn how to improve the model. He thought that adding more features would only make the model worse.

query: What did the professor think about the noise?
summary: The professor thought that the noise was affecting the model. He thought that it was a good idea to improve the model by adding more noise to the model, but he was concerned that the model was not performing as well as it should. The professor explained that the problem was probably due to the mismatch between the noise and the model's initial range of SNR.

query: What did the professor think about LDA?
summary: The professor thought that LDA was a good idea. He thought that the neural net should be able to distinguish between different kinds of features. He also mentioned that the LDA could be used in a neural net. The professor also thought that a parallel VAD without neural nets could be useful.

query: What did the professor think about the silence?
summary: The professor thought that the silence was too high and that the model was not discriminating well between speech and nonspeech. He thought that it would be interesting to look at the correlation between silence and speech noise. He suggested that they could run the model on different test sets, including large vocabulary, and see how the model performed.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the remote control should be flat inside and there should be standard buttons on the top and the more complex buttons under the thing. query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: The group took the input from the previous meeting, especially from the marketing and industrial design, to check on the customer needs and feasibility. query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
